description.text:
This is a derivative supershape that I liked.  It sort of reminds me of a starfruit (but inverted at the ends).
It prints fine with no support.  I was looking for a super shape that could be easily printed.
dave

scale([10,10,10])
RenderSuperShape(
shape1 = supershape(m=58, n1=.9, n2=.9, n3=.9, a=.9, b=.9),
shape2=supershape(m=119, n1=.190, n2=9, n3=.1, a=1, b=1),
phisteps = 8,
thetasteps = 64,
points=false,
pointcolor=[1,1,1],
wireframe=false,
faces=true);

I call this a Micro Chess Set because each square of the board is 1" x 1" making the total board size 8" x 8". In order to artificially add weight to the pieces, each chess piece has a small magnet in its base, and each board square has a threaded hole for a set screw. The pieces are based on Staunton chess sets. The board was inspired by other chess boards on Thingiverse. In order to save time and resources a paper board has also been included; if you choose to use the paper board it is unnecessary to 3D print any of the board components or purchase the magnets and setscrews. A complete set will require the following: Light Colored Pieces
2 x Piece Bishop
1 x Piece King
2 x Piece Knight
8 x Piece Pawn
1 x Piece Queen
2 x Piece Rook Dark Colored Pieces
2 x Piece Bishop
1 x Piece King
2 x Piece Knight
8 x Piece Pawn
1 x Piece Queen
2 x Piece Rook Light Colored Board Squares
18 x Board Middle
3 x Board EdgeA
3 x Board EdgeB
3 x Board EdgeC
3 x Board EdgeD
1 x Board CornerA
1 x Board CornerC Dark Colored Board Squares
18 x Board Middle
3 x Board EdgeA
3 x Board EdgeB
3 x Board EdgeC
3 x Board EdgeD
1 x Board CornerB
1 x Board CornerD Other Components
32 x Magnet (1/4" diameter x 1/16" height)
http://www.digikey.com/product-search/en?keywords=469-1005-ND
64 x Set Screw (1/4"-20 thread x 3/16" length)
http://www.mcmaster.com/#92311a532/=10t4414 Printing Recommendations:
The pieces, not board, should be printed with 100% fill.
The knight will require a support, this can likely be added by your slicing software.
If printing the paper chess board, it is best to print it without scaling it up or down.

This was designed to fit the Raspberry Pi NOIR camera with 2 Infra-Red lights. The unit I bought is http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Raspberry-Pi-2-model-B-NoIR-Night-camera-With-free-2-IR-light/32391489437.html I printed mine in black ABS with 0.2mm layers For avoidance of doubt, this item is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. See http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/4.0/ for more details.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

N/A

Notes: I used ABS but PLA should also work.

Some disassembly and assembly required. Remove the rubber boots over the opt-resistor light sensors on each IR LED board, being careful not to lose the tiny lenses. Clear the holes in the housing to 5mm using a 5mm drill bit then insert the lenses into the housing (mine were press-fitted and required no glue). Insert the camera board, with the two LED boards behind it, and use 4 small screws to attach the three boards to the housing.

Fun party picks for football fans. This is an easy print because they are flat on the bottom. The lacing is raised so you can paint or use a permanent marker to highlight them. You can glue two together for a more realistic football. The only thing you need to be careful of is not to bend the toothpick end when peeling it off the build platform. Use PETG (which is theoretically food safe although some argue that bacteria could grow in the layers) or PLA. You might like these other picks and sticks I have designed:
Football Party Picks
Spring Flower, Butterfly and Bee Multi Purpose Picks
Great Outdoors Swizzle Sticks and Picks
Labor Day Party Picks and Sticks
Say I Love You
Lucky St. Patrick's Day Party Picks and Sticks
Breast Cancer Awareness Collection
Holiday Party Picks and Swizzle Sticks Even though these are meant for a hard filament I create these designs to encourage people to try out flexible filaments or get some new interesting colors of flexibles. For info on purchasing samples of 6 different types of flexible filament see flexyfilament.com

description.text:
Roomba horns prevent the roomba from getting stucker under your furniture. This simple model works really great for me. I tested this for the 620 roomba model. Assembly:
See the attached image for attachement of the horns to the roomba. Drill holes from behind the bumper at the red crosses (disassembly is done as described here: https://de.ifixit.com/Guide/Disassembling+iRobot+Roomba+551+Bumper/22501). Take short wood screws. If the holes are too loose, just adjust the model to get a tight fit.

title: E-Z Tear - Cling Film Tearing Tool

description.text:
Most household use cling film... and waste a lot in the process. Although this is not a big thing E-Z Tear is a really simple practical solution that will reduce cling film consumption and make using it more "EZ"... cling film manufacturers will not like this simple little money saving tool! The issues E-Z Tear addresses are: (1) The tear strips on cling film boxes get damaged so no longer tear well... with an E-Z tear available you can use it instead. (2) If you are using a cling film refill but don't have a box with a tear strip use E-Z tear to tear off cling film as required. It works much better than scissors or trying to rip it off with no tearing surface. (3) The tearing strip on cling film boxes means you have to tear off full width strips. That means significant waste when you only need a small piece to cover a small container. It's easy to end up using 3 times the amount you need. E-Z Tear lets you tear out small pices to suit. E-Z Tear is a simple easy to use tool. However, there are a couple of points to be aware that will make sure it works effectively for you:

  • Always use the E-Z Tear on a flat surface-

  • Place the E-Z Tear over the cling film and hold it down firmly against the cling film (on the flat surface)

  • Always use short sharp tears in an upward and sideways movement against the teeth on the E-Z Tear. This will help ensure a good clean tear.

  • Tear across the roll to the width required then turn the E-Z Tear 90 degrees and tear again to remove the piece of cling film. It's "E-Z".

  • Not holding the E-Z Tear down firmly enough or a too slow movement in the wrong direction will result in stretched cling film... not torn cling film.
    • Every home that uses cling film should have one of these handy little helpers ready for use as/when required. It's a small and extremely "EZ" print that will recover more than its filament cost in next to no time. Please refer to the images and print settings for more information. Note: If you like this take a look at the rest of my practical and fun designs!

title: Toggle Latch Extruder for 1.75mm MakerGear Groove Mount

description.text:
Some call it an over-center mechanism. The idea is to eliminate fasteners and springs while providing very fast access to change color or clean up after trying to extrude through a cold nozzle. It's also a little more open than the standard extruder, so it's easier to clean, or to just watch the gear turn.
I got rid of the springs because I always tightened the screws of the standard extruder until the springs were fully compressed. They were only acting as spacers. Also, I figured that even if they weren't fully compressed, they would only tend to add variability to the system.
The arched shape of the latch link provides the spring action to hold the latch closed. An early experiment without the arch simply broke. I also experimented with a ramp inside the extruder frame to guide filament into the hot end without opening the extruder, but this just made room for the filament to buckle and jam.
I have maybe a dozen or so hours of printing on this design. It's not perfect, but it might at least give people some ideas.

This design is specific to 1.75 mm filament. I also uploaded a STEP file for a 3mm version, but I haven't tested that. The zip file contains SolidWorks 2012 files.
The files as printed won't grip the filament as tightly as the standard MG extruder. Sand or trim the printed pieces until you get an e steps calibration similar to the standard extruder. It should be very consistent after that adjustment.
There is a socket at the top of the frame where the filament enters. This is meant to accept the Bowden extruder tube that came with my MG Prusa kit. I use a Bowden arrangement to feed the extruder so the X axis never has to pull on the spool.
The dimple-and-pocket hinge design isn't really very robust, so it may need some trimming, or simply may not hold together when open, depending on your print settings and quality. A slightly larger version might work better.

Notes: I printed mine @ 1.5mm layer, with brim and support. Brim may not be necessary.

Tips: Use just a regular size paper clip, Leaving the big radius end alone, bend out the rest of the paper clip straight. May need to straighten it out with the pliers to make it go through the holes in the print easier.
The paper clip needs to be cut to length. See the photo that shows the opening where the support was is 39mm which can be used as a guide for cutting the length of clip.
Insert long end of clip through one of the holes in the end, then continue with the shorter end in the other hole.
Using the needle nose pliers, bend the cut end over the center groove as shown inside the picture.
Should be all set to go for an 18650.

description.text: This is a bottom body part for Cheerson CX-10C quadcopter, that nice nano quad with a camera. It's a fun toy, but original bottom body part is fragile and starts developing cracks and feet breaking off only after a few hard (like falling on wooden floor from 1.5m height after hitting a wall and losing control) crashes. I've looked on eBay for spare CX-10C body, and it cost somewhere around 10 euros a pop, which is about 10 times as much I would pay for such a thing. And since I was tired of putting broken feet back and gluing/soldering them on, I designed this. It may not look as sophisticated as the original piece, but it does the job of holding everything together pretty good. It doesn't have original piece's latches on the end of each beam, but it still clamps each motor in place good enough (it seems) only by 3 (kinda tight) lips and standoff at the bottom. As for the flight ability of this quadcopter, it doesn't seem to suffer much - I'm still getting the same ~2m15s flight time I used to get with original body part on. It flies fine, it does flips, everything seems alright. So now I don't have to worry about breaking its feet again, since I can print the replacement for the only really vulnerable part (props don't seem to break easily, they just bend instead) in just a little under 30 minutes :) UPDATE 25/01/16 Adding new version with more refined feet - see bottom21.stl. UPDATE 31/01/16 Adding CAD files to the thing. There's also a GitHub repository now: https://github.com/KP1533TM2/cx10-parts

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Migbot Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.08mm per layer, 1 perimeter-wide walls

Infill:

100% inside thicker parts, everything else is just walls.

Notes: Slice this thing upside down, it was designed to be printed from top to bottom. I've had some troubles tuning Slic3r so it would actually use bridge settings for small gaps, so you may want to turn supports on. All "mandatory" supports are already in the model. This piece on the photos was accidentally done with 0.15mm layer height and it turned out fine, although I intended to print it with 0.08mm height. Everything from 0.1mm and below should be alright.
In case of Slic3r, all walls should be 1 perimeter wide. Curaengine seems to do it's own thing with two perimeters very close to each other, but curaengine-sliced print with supports turned out fine, too. Battery compartment grill relies on your printer's ability to bridge gaps nicely, so you may need to fine-tune that. Printing with PLA worked absolutely fine for me, but YMMV.
And just for the record, I was using 0.3mm nozzle and Slic3r for slicing. If you get fuzzy, non-plain, fine zigzag pattern perimeters with Slic3r, try to increase extrusion width until all perimeters become normal and straight. UPDATE 25/01/16 I was mostly using Slic3r before, but I'm starting to get a hang of Curaengine now, and I like it. Besides being faster than Slic3r, it also seems to produce better results and has simpler setup. Having said that, over the past few days I tried to print this thing sliced with Curaengine both with and without supports, and they both come out fine :)

Snap off all the supports with small (preferably sharp ;) ) side cutters, and just fit it on your quad.
Start fitting motors first (be careful not to pinch the wiring), make sure camera fits in place, and also be careful not to pinch and push the battery too hard. There's not much else to it, really.

OpenSCAD and LibreCAD were involved :)
I may post sources in the near future, since I need to tidy them up a bit...

Taking a simple concept and making it kind of industrial stylish for practical use.  The idea is a flowing I-Beam that supports a 2 X 10" board (Keep in mind that a 10" wide board is really on 9.25" wide). The bracket is pretty big, make sure it fits in your printer - I printed it vertically; didn't need support. The holes are for a #10 screw.  No idea how much it can support. I used 3 foot long 2 X 10 and am using it to keep my 3D printing stuff organized.  The brackets that I made were in 1.75 mm orange PLA from MakerBot on a SeeMeCNC printer.  Probably used bed at 60 C and probably 210 C for the extruder temp.  Fan kicks in on the third layer.  I think I used 20% infill.
Used Inventor.

comments.text: Hi JustForFun.  I agree strength-wise that printing vertically is probably the weakest.  Your idea sounds pretty good so supports aren't needed.  The other way that I was considering was to print the top down and remove the nub that holds the shelf on.  I can make a model if anyone wants it without the nub on it.  I can also add a hole for a dowel or screw to replace the nub to hold the shelf back.
comments.author: Ocono3D

comments.text: That looks really sharp!  If you print it vertically as shown, I'd be a little concerned that the top is in tension, and will be trying to pull apart the fused layers. That us usually weaker than pulling along a layer.  It would be stronger to split it in half vertically, lay each side flat, print two halves and glue or fuse them together. That would avoid printing with supports, and you would have continuous strands of filament along the top to give it more strength.
comments.author: JustForFun

title: FlashForge Pro mount for Arlo Camera (Netgear)

description.text: This is a simple mount meant to hold an Arlo Camera (netgear security cam) to keep tabs on prints. This does not include the needed hardware and may need some tweaking to accommodate whatever hardware you choose to use (hinge pin and screw to secure camera). If you are feeling adventurous, you can also use magnets as the arlo camera has a powerful mag mount...just something for a quick release option. Here is the onshape link, just create an account, copy the model to your workspace and modify as you see fit: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/8d7c748b270b44d2baa9f908/w/7d9609718d96462bb0c34331/e/7e5f3eadad3144a3a762d1f8 Let me know if this does not work and you want to use it.

Printer:

Flashforge Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

medium

Infill:

45%

Notes: On a side note here....if you want, i can cut this up into pieces so that it does not require support...then just a little glue and you're golden.

Some Assembly required There is need for a hinge pin and camera mount bolt (1/4-20 UNC). As i used whatever screws and bolts i had available, the thickness of the area with the mounting screw is 15mm thick...this will most likely vary from person to person depending on what bolt you have to do this with...I would recommend going to the onshape file and modifying it as needed to meet your needs then export, slice, and print.
With calipers I used calipers to measure the critical dims, created basic shapes to reference, then designed around these...

remixed_from.title: iPhone 6/6s and Apple Watch stand (case compatible)

description.text: iPhone 6/6s stand remixed from Shodan's model with the watch stand. I liked the design of the stand, but am not blessed with an Apple Watch so I had to modify it slightly. This currently fits an iPhone 6/6s without a case. (I've never used or needed a case myself). However I'm happy to modify and upload any additional variants to fit your case if you can provide the dimensions. Alternatively I've remodelled in SW and uploaded the .sldprt so feel free to adjust it yourself! I've also added a tray to the base with the intention of fitting a lump of steel for weight, but may be more useful left open as a tray. 26/01/16, added trial stand for "otterbox" case. Work in progress (WIP). If you want to check for fit without wasting too much material/time, try slicing it 22mm up and print only the top half. 11/05/16, updated "otterbox" version following feedback. Lightning connector seat lowered by 2mm. If this is too much, a small spacer can be used to set the height. 19/07/16, added version for apple silicone case. Untested work in progress. Tested and approved. 06/09/16, Updated version for apple silicone case to add 1mm to connector height; Added [untested] version for Tech20 Sport case.

author: Arcaded

description.text:
Similar to an ACME animator peg bar, minus their proprietary rectangular registration keys and therefor nullifying the requirement of having that really expensive special hole-puncher. The cotton blend paper is really nice for rolling, though. 
Go to any local thrift store and pick up a three-ring hole-puncher and you'll be off animating.
This animation peg bar is built from the ground up by a traditional animator. It has a thick, rigid frame and practically a zero slide tolerance. I tried a peg bar already in Thingiverse's database and either my hole puncher is off or the measurements were incorrect. Any sliding is simply unacceptable for animation. This is serious business. ( I really could have a unique hole-puncher )
Pictured is me and my portable animation "station". The little furry animal is Bonkers D. Bobcat ( anthropomorphic cat ) in Zootopia / Zootropolis Z.P.D. uniform belongs to Disney. Also, I traditionally animate on scrap paper because some people just give it away. How cool is that?

description.text:
These are 2 parts to install a DyzEnd Hot End on a Rostock MAX. It should also fit the Orion and Rostock MAX v1 as they have the same effector. The DyzEnd is a new Hot End using stainless steel and titanium to allow printing at up to 500C. They have a growing assortment of tips. The box I got contained a 0.5 and 0.35 tip, cables, 30w cartridge, high temperature thermistor.
http://shop.dyzedesign.com/dyzend The top part has 3 slots to slide electrical cables and keep everything tidy around the print head of this 3D Delta printer.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15mm

Infill:

100

Notes: Print in ABS to better support the temperature around the Hot End. Both parts are printed upside down; this removes the need for supports.

Installation on your printer Once you printed your parts, you need to disassemble the original head; remove the original 1.75" screws, fans, hot end, aluminium tubular spacers and top plate, leaving the effector plate on.
Follow the manufacturer's instructions to assemble the DyzEnd:
http://dyzedesign.com/support/dyzend-technical-support/dyzend-assembly/ Reassemble with the newly printed parts and 2" screws. The top flange of the new head slides into the U slot of the printed part with the 3 legs. The flat print part goes on top with the small recess in the middle locking the new head flange in place. There is a thin gap between the 3 legged part and top part. That gap goes away by tightening the 2" screws. Reconnect the electrical cables. I installed connectors on my cables to make it easy to swap from the original head to this new head.
I oriented the DyzEnd head that the fan was clear of the 3 posts and the temperature sensor aligns with one of the recess in the effector plate. I still had to file a notch in the effector to leave enough for the heat sensor and its wires. The new hot head is seated in the U slot of the 3-legged printed parts and centered. The top plate goes on top with the small round recess locking the flange of the DyzEnd in place. Close-up of the newly installed head. Firmware updates The new DyzEnd head uses a different thermistor optimized to measure the temperatures in the 200-500 deg C range. You will need to modify your Repetier firmware to support that high temperature thermistor. I first had to migrate to Repetier 0.92 from the original 0.91 firmware I had on my Rostock. Follow the instructions provided by Dyze Design here:
http://dyzedesign.com/support/dyzend-technical-support/dyzend-firmware-configuration/#repetier Cables are passing through the side slots of the top printed part making for a nice and tidy setup.

description.text:
This is a model for a toy submarine. I printed this for my nine month old baby to play with during bath time. "under supervision" The model features a spinning seven blade prop. Also a detailed hatch, periscope and handle. The toy fills with water and sinks. I have added holes for 2-3 pennies to be added in case its too top heavy. 
Enjoy!

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple White

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.18

Infill:

20-25%

Notes: Print the bottom and middle as is with a 20% infill and support. The prop should be printed with 100% infill with support everywhere. The upper with 25% or more infill and support with a 10 line brim. This should yield a strong toy overall. You should be able to scale it up slightly if you want a bigger toy. First one to print a yellow version wins.

Finishing the toy You may need to carefully use a X-Acto knife to free the prop from the axle. Take care when removing the support material from the top section of the prop so it will fit on the bottom and middle sections. Sand most parts then use super glue to affix the sections together. Be careful not to glue the prop onto the axle.

description.text:
Check back here as I post files that I've modified as I complete Gael's Stomach. StomSupportCombinedV2: - this is both halves combined. title: InMoov Torso Mods for the XBoxOne Kinect

description.text:
Here are all of the parts required to mount an XBoxOne Kinect sensor into your InMoov. All of the frame pieces are drop in replacements for the originals, and I've verified the fit. SensorMount-K1 is what really locks the Kinect into the torso. Please see the render for how that works. Print in the default orientation with support, and slide it in when you mount the sensor. Updates
2016-01-27 KinectSideHolder updated with mountpoints for SideRIbsCover
2016-01-25 interkinectmid, added back clearance for chest piece, added hole for kinect cable routing out through back.
2016-01-25 sensormount updated, fixed recessed screw holes
2016-01-24 recessed the sensor a bit more. Frame parts updated

author: anacastillejo

title: Chassis for Drawing Bot with Batt Holders

description.text: Another variant on MakersBox Arduino Drawing Bot. Both the Pro Trinket from Adafruit and my DIY arduino solution work fine with 6V so I thought it would be a perfect opportunity to try to incorporate my battery packs (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1096639) I used the original battery pack design versus the newer slimmer model because the larger space puts less stress on the printed plastic and I had the space under the bot to use them. I soldered the leads to make the 6V pack but only because I was testing soldering to stainless steel. Pressure fit 22 gauge jumpers will work just fine for a solderless build. The result is a smaller bot than my previous model (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1287264) with the same functionality. However, thinking past the drawing aspect, a smaller robot may make it through a maze a bit easier... Both work great, and the credit should be given to MakersBox for a great design.
Recommend using countersunk M3 screws to mount the ball caster in order to give you a flat area onto which you can position your breadboard with dual-sided tape.

The battery tray has now evolved into a multi-purpose part. In addition to the original basic version, there are now two special versions which allow you to add other neat features to your Racer 250. See updates at the bottom of this summary. Eachine, in their infinite wisdom (not) has decided to save pennies and omit the battery tray from this popular budget mini-quad racer.
http://wikirotors.com/index.php?title=Eachine_Racer_250#Versions
The omission of this part in the newest version 5 model virtually guarantees that the CC3D flight controller board will be damaged and the USB connector will be sheared off in a mild crash. This is absolutely ludicrous because 250 class racing quads are specifically designed to be crash resistant. I have included two basic versions of the part. Both require 2.5mm screws which pass through holes already present on the Racer 250 lower frame (PCB).
One version is for 12mm long screws, and the other is for 16mm long screws. The 16mm version is preferred for greater strength, but the 12mm version can be used if you don't have any 16mm screws. The part is designed to accept standard 5mm hex head M2.5 nuts. I believe this part should actually be stronger than the original because it doesn't use the skinny little standoffs. It also has a larger contact area with the battery and is more centrally located. There is enough clearance for thin battery straps, but probably not the big fat ones. Update 3/13/16:
Created revised versions with servo mount point and bracket that is designed to work with my FPV camera tilt mount. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1393669 Update 3/18/16:
Created revised versions with a 36x36mm platform and 30.5mm center holes to allow attachment of a receiver mount or other experimental part.
See the 20 degree version of my D4R-II receiver mount as an example.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1413058/#files

Printer:

Custom built Kossel 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 micron

Notes: I usually print in PLA, but decided to print it in ABS because I thought it might be more impact resistant. In reality, it probably doesn't matter.

An upgrade from the original one. This time with 3x the lighting! A mount for your Printrbot Simple Metal that will hold 4 strips of LED Light Strips (6 sections) for lighting your work area. Rests above the Extruder plate, with hangovers in the back that keep it quite secure. As with the original Ptinrbot LED Light Strip: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1276019
This is based off of SMD5050 LED Light Strips such as the one found here:
http://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00JQV6Q4I 105ish-mm in width for two double section strips of LED's, 50ish-mm in depth should be right about the length of a 3-LED strip piece at the cut section. Install the four strips of led's, wire them together, run some wire, and wire it up to your power supply (if you have the ATX style) or to a power supply of your choice. Might have to work a bit (move it around a bit, NOT cut it) the wire for thebed levelling laser to get the right side around the wire.

remixed_from.author: zaphi
remixed_from.title: Fatshark Attitude V2 FPV Goggle faceplate mod

description.text: This is a remix Zaphi made a cool little clip that will let you put a fatshark face plate on your Attitude V2 goggles even though they are not meant for them. Don't know if it was me or my printer, but although Zaphi's design worked, I had problems with it. They were too loose and would often fall out, and they poked my forehead when I had them resting there prepping for a flight. So I made then alot tighter, and rounded them so they didn't poke so bad. Try it out and we all know that everyones printer is different. If it doesn't work for you try Zaphi's. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fCoSiUsdFAw

Printer:

Hacked DaVinci

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: For those using Simplify3D, While it is a great program and I truly love it, they frustrate me with the fact that if something is smaller than your extruder width they simply ignore it and leave it out of the print. So you end up with half of a clip. My nozzle is .4mm but I had to set my extruder width to .38mm in order for this to print complete. I have included a picture so you can see the setting I am referring too. Be sure to preview the print before you send it to make sure the entire job will be completed.

comments.text:
They are just the white face plate you find everywhere, either visit your local hobby shop or search online for Fatshark Faceplate. They are designed for the Dominator series. Both the V2 and the HD, and they snap onto those.
Well they won't snap on the Attitudes so someone made clips, and I modified the clip to better fit my needs.
GL
KT

This object is a model of our earth. It shows the different layers of our earth and their names. This model provides a hand on experience for younger kids in science.

Designing: I started off by looking at an image online that showed the layers of the earth very similarly to my final product. I then modeled a wedge in autodesk and added canals to it so you could tell the different layers. I added the layer's names on the side of the wedge. I wanted to create a hands on model instead of just an image for kids to use.

Objectives: To help provide kids with a hands on experience of our earth Audiences Children in any general science class who is learning about the Earth. Preparation All you need is a 3d-printer and software. Steps
  • Download the object file
  • load into printer software
  • rotate, scale, etc to fit your printing needs
  • PRINT!
    • Results You should have a model of our earth's layers

I was having a hard time getting retract settings right on my 3d printer so i searched the net for configuration files. I came across lulzbot that has cura settings for almost all filaments commercially available. I also recently changed my firmware to the one used on lulzbot printers just slightly modified. If you want to use my firmware you'll need to mod it for your setup. I have it set for dual extruders,temp sensor 11 both hotends, auto-leveling enabled and mk8 direct drive gear. The cube is there only because its needed to post thisI will soon add the new firmware settings I'm using with wades extruder, which i find easier to use strength and heat wise.

title: CTC/FlashForge Creator Z-Axis guide rod supports

description.text:
Use a total of four of these to support top and bottom of each of the two Z axis guide rods. The original wooden supports allow a lot of play.
Use M3 cap-head stainless bolts from the original wooden mount to secure thing to printer frame. Only two of the original four bolts required.
I printed using 0.2mm layers using ABS @230degC and 110degC bed with no issues using Simplify3D. Supports are needed in cap head bolt recesses.

comments.text: Before you printed these did you have Z-wobble? And did using this solve for that problem?
comments.author: collinmcmanus

comments.text: I was having a lot of trouble with imperfections such as ringing. The wobble of the Z Axis shafts affects X and Y accuracy, not Z accuracy, so was the most important axis to fix. It certainly tightened up the accuracy of the prints. Switching to Simplify3D and SailFish firmware made a bigger difference, but I think that eliminating slop wherever I can has dramatically improved the printer.
comments.author: collinmcmanus

comments.text: Okay, so I'm still fairly new to the entire 3d printing thing. Do you mind explaining to me what the Simplify3D and the SailFish firmware are and if you are able could you tell me how i could go about doing that?
comments.author: SteveEvans

comments.text: Sailfish, see http://www.sailfishfirmware.com/, is an open source firmware for MakerBot (and compatible) printers. It's designed to work with the ReplicatorG slicer. Whilst the firmware it certainly very good, and allows much quicker printing without impacting quality, I could never manage to tune out all the imperfections with ReplicatorG. So I heard about Simplify3D, see https://www.simplify3d.com, an alternate slicer that unfortunately isn't free, currently costing $149. I've never heard anything but praise for it. I decided to buy a copy (there are no trial versions) and all the print problems I'd been struggling with just vanished. It quite literally transformed the printer. Seriously, get a copy. You not find anybody who's used it say any different!
comments.author: collinmcmanus

comments.text: Okay, thank you very much.
comments.author: SteveEvans

comments.text: Great part. Pretty much essential to solve Z axis wobbles on CTC replicator dual and other plywood laser cut chassis printers.

I was having trouble getting the smaller gears to print because of the overhang. I used OpenSCAD to fill in the bottom of the hole on each gear so that there was a clean bridge. I left enough of the hole to act as a guide for the drill. The scad files are created demonstrating how to do this.   
The import feature in OpenSCAD provides a convenient way to make simple additions and deletions to an existing part if the only thing you have is the STL file.
Print the v2 versions of the gears, then use a 3mm drill (ideally held in a pin vice) to clean out the hole.

title: Laser Cut RepRap Melzi PCB Cover

description.text:
I used to be paranoid I was going to short out one of my Melzi controllers by waving a screwdriver or some such into it. Now I've got a printer that looks tidier and is a lot harder to short out!  
These covers bolt either side of your Melzi boards and have a row of cable loops along the back. There are also access holes for the jumpers, expansion heaer and the reset button.  
If that wasn't enough they've even got the RepRap logo etched into them as well!

The files contain two covers, one for a master board and another for a slave. If you don't have a tri-colour Mendel then you're only going to need the right hand ones.  
Setup your laser cutter to etch the green RepRap logo and cut along the lines, then you're ready to tidy up your printer.  
I used 10mm long M3 standoffs to sandwich the PCB and the covers together. A piece of small tube will do just as well if that's what you've got lying around.

author: CBiker

description.text:
These steampunk goggles are designed to use 52mm photographic filters as lenses. I used cheap ND8 filters from dx.com which cost about $6 each.
The auxiliary lenses with the sweet orange coating were salvaged from a found pair of cheap binoculars.
The strap is a makeshift solution - made from black fabric tape (somewhat like duct tape) folded over on itself. A strap with a bit of stretch would be an improvement.

I printed with PLA using a raft and support on makerware and a Replicator. Support is essential to support the outer ring and the auxiliary mounting lugs.
The bridge (over the nose) is printed separately, and clips into the outer ring of the goggles.
If you printed in PLA, the bridge can to be warmed and bent to adjust how the goggles fit to your face. I poured some boiling water into a bowl to heat the bridge to pliability.
I also used hot water to push-fit the little auxiliary lenses into their mounts. Obviously you can use the aux lugs for whatever you want, or leave them empty.
I painted the buckles with copper Liquid Leaf paint. They looked fine unpainted too.
The strap holes are designed for a strap up to about 25mm wide.
I was able to thread the lenses into the eye pieces without glue. If your sizing isn't spot on you could hot-glue the lens in place. The ideal solution in my mind would be to use two pairs of filters, remove the glass from one pair (by unscrewing the locking ring) and hot-glue just the threaded rings into the eye pieces, then screw the other filters into the rings. Because the filters can be stacked, you can add polarizing lenses on top if you want.

author: ZeFrenchie

title: ZMR250 split top plate - low rider mod

description.text:
Still a work in progress, but feel free to print and test it out.
I wanted a quick and easy way to do a low rider mod without having to cut the original carbon fibre top plate just in case i want to rollback my changes.
So I split the top plate.. the "back" piece will sit lower, and then the "front" piece will sit higher to accommodate FPV cameras up front.
Just use the appropriate standoffs that you will need. I included the original 35mm standoff.. load it into your slicer and then scale only the z height to however low you want to go, and print as many as you need.
The battery should now sit lower as it rests on top of the "back" piece.
The front small piece has the holes which can still accommodate the original camera plate too.

This is a rotor blade for a T-Rex 450 RC Helicopter optimized for very stable flight. The lightweight rotors provide much better stability over stock rotor blades. You can print this with supports which creates a very rigid blade preventing flapping, or print hollow for lighter weight but still having very stable flight. These rotors don't require balancing and provide more lift than stock blades. Another added benefit is when crashed, the blades break-away which reduce the damage to other helicopter parts.

• Print with out without a raft.
  • Print either with zero infill or 15% infill for extra rigidity
  • Print with 2 shells
  • Place helper disks at the tip of the blade to prevent warping. (File>Examples>Helper Discs)

comments.text:
I wouldn't use these on a 450 class helicopter so I scaled them down to use them on a blade mcpx. They perform pretty well as long as you don't use negative pitch. If you try to fly upside-down your helicopter will fall down as a stone ;)

title: E3D V6 Mount for Da Vinci PRO no wiring

description.text: First off, thanks to thebak3 some of my design was inspired by his. I made this because I wanted an E3D V6 on my Da Vinci PRO, and I wanted to keep my stock fan. Installation is pretty straight forward you will only need the original components from your stock hot end, and #4 sheet metal screws in various lengths. be careful when you put the heat sink into the fan shroud, it may crack if your not careful. you may want to warm it up a bit first. I made the hole for the pneumatic quick connect larger that thebak3's because I wanted to use the one that came with my E3D because that is all I had (use "Mount5mmFitting" if you need ther smaller thread like the one on the Da Vinci). Be sure to mount the two pieces together before you put on the fan because the screw holes to connect the two pieces together are actually underneath the fan. I know its not super pretty, I will probably do a few iterations of this but hey it works so put it on your machine!

description.text:
Box done following a tutorial to create a box with compartments used to store movement dials for the X-wing miniatures game.
This is the box as i'm printing it now. with these sizes I can use the box either to store dial (they will sit a little loose) or small bases and sticks. I store the base and the assembled sticks in the same division and the stick is positioned diagonally. Of course, that is what i do and you can do as you please :)
The design could be used as well to create a box to store small bases and sticks by setting the base dimensions and a second row percentage to around 15% to create a small space for the sticks. In this case, the size of the dial should be set to the size of the sticks so the lid can be closed. Edit 3/7/16: Fixed an error with the lid guides
Edit 4/22/16: I'm no longer making any changes on this design so I'll remove the work in progress mark.

description.text:
This is a set of parts for a card game that can be played for money or just for fun. It includes a one cent coin, a five cent coin, and a cup to hold the coins. The quantity of cups and coins can be printed as desired. I printed 1 large cup and 4 smaller cups sized at 80% of the original along with 42 one cent coins and 40 five cent coins which accommodates four players. The coin cups can be scaled if you prefer, as I did, to 80% to make 4 smaller cups and leave the cup at 100% to be used for the pot. Print as many 80% cups as you will have players, up to 7, maybe 8. The game requires two decks of card, three if 5 or more players. The rules for the game are as follows: For 4 players, I let the bank give out 4 five cent coins and 10 one cent coins to each player for a starting bank roll. If a player runs out before the end of the game, he/she can buy more from the bank. SHANGHAI – RUM A LA MARCELLE GAME RULES Everyone puts a nickle in the pot
DEAL – 12 cards – 1 to 4 – 2 decks ---- 5,6, or 7 people – 3 decks
JOKERS and TWO's are wild
ACE can be high or low
SET = 3 or more of a kind as in 4 hearts, 4 diamonds, 4 clubs
RUN = 4 or more of the same suit as in 3,4,5,6 of Diamonds You may buy a JOKER by paying $.05 to the owner when it is laid down and by trading it with the card it represents. You cannot buy after you spread.
Spread can only include the initial cards even if you have more, they have to be played on next turn.
You cannot trade with other wild card.
Anyone can claim the top of the discard pile but must also draw an extra penalty card from the staock without discarding.
No new matched sets are allowed.
After you spread, you can play on any player's sets.
Each hand ends when a player has played all his cards.
Loosers put a penny in for each card left in their hand.
The winner takes the nickles, pennies, pot. FIRST HAND -------- 2 SETS OF THREE
SECOND HAND ------- 1 SET OF THREE AND 1 RUN OF FOUR
THIRD HAND -------- 2 RUNS OF FOUR
FOUTH HAND -------- 3 SETS OF THREE
FIFTH HAND -------- 2 SETS OF THREE AND 1 RUN OF FOUR
SIXTH HAND -------- 2 RUNS OF FOUR AND 1 SET OF THREE
SEVENTH HAND ------ 3 RUNS OF FOUR -- DEAL 13 CARDS FOR THIS HAND

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

30%

Notes: I printed the cups in clear PLA and the coins in contrasting colors, yellow on black and black on white. I edited the GCODE to insert an M600 command at the point where the text layer first begins. M600 pauses the print and lets you change filament if you are using Repetier. I printed five cent coins on one 200x200 bed and and 42 one cent coins in a second print. This provides enough coins for a game with 4 players.

description.text: SAE Socket= standard US Fractions This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lrFwgdI03NS

There are a variety of old ultrafast lenses cheaply available. These lenses, usually marked between f/0.75 and f/1.6, typically have no aperture iris, no focus mechanism, and a giant external screw thread intended for mounting. They generally can't focus to infinity even on a mirrorless body, and IQ is scary soft, but sometimes that's a feature.... Anyway, I originally mounted these lenses by gluing an M42-to-A-mount adapter on the back (as I described in my Instructable, http://www.instructables.com/id/Using-Ultra-Fast-Lenses-on-DSLR-Cameras/ ). Instead, I've now built 3D-printable focusing E-mount adapters where the lens screws in using the large external thread (see 2nd photo) and can be focused by partial unscrewing. One mount has a 60mm thread that works with my Kowa 55mm f/1 and 42mm f/0.75; the other has an 80mm thread that works with my XR-Heligon 95mm f/1.3. The E-mount flange is a new design that should fit both older Sony E-mount bodies and the newer all-metal E-mounts (they have been tested with NEX-5 and A7II). In fact, the flange on the 80mm adapter has a different internal profile from the 60mm one, because the rear element of the XR-Heligon is huge and a standard-thickness E-mount could vignette. The last couple of photos were taken using the purple PLA adapters on an A7II and NEX-5. The kiwi was using the Rodenstock XR-Heligon and the princess ornament was using one of the Kowas. Note that the large flat on the adapters makes it difficult (but not impossible) to access the E-mount body lens release button and the 80mm adapter just barely clears the grip on my NEX-5, but the only way to avoid these issues would be to mount the lens farther away from the sensor, which would limit the focus range.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: The adapters print with the E-mount side up. This means there is a huge unsupported flat under the E-mount flange -- and that needs supports when printing. Both cura and slic3r had issues making good support structures, so I have designed-in a support that should simply be broken out of the center of the adapter after printing.

Break-out the internal support It should be pretty each to remove -- I twisted it out with pliers. Work the screw threads The screw threads should print directly usable, but it may be helpful to work it back and forth a bit to clean-up any of the usual 3D-printing strings, etc. You might even need to file-off a drip or two on the threads or the flat inside of the adapter. I recommend working the threads a bit to test fit, filing a little if needed, and then using water to clean off the plastic dust. Paint inside black I usually use opaque black filament for adapters, but here I used dark purple. To ensure no light leaks, I painted the inside of the E-mount flange and the inside back of the E-mount flange with flat black latex paint. This isn't really needed, but the paint fills any pinholes nicely and it can't hurt. You don't need to paint the screw thread, etc. Paint the alignment dot There is an alignment dot on the outside for aligning the adapter with the E-mount on the body for mounting. I put a dot of white paint in the cylindrical cavity printed for that purpose. It's the white dot visible in the 3rd photo. I use white because Sony uses white for the corresponding mark on the body.

title: GEEETech Prusa I3 Heated Bed Clip

description.text:
Because of the placement of the solder joints on the top of the heated bed, small binder clips are not deep enough to clip the glass.  This is a simple low-profile replacement for the back of your heated bed.
With small binder clips on the front, there is about 12mm between the rear edge of the bed glass and the bed PCB, so the clips have a 12mm deep throat.  It fits snugly over a 2mm PCB with 3mm thick glass.

Notes:

description.header:
Some Notes:
1. Print 8x Bolts to mount the gear bearings.
2. Gear bearings may require some hand rework to remove flashing or filament from low quality prints. The bearings WILL stick if the gear teeth have extra material on them. (use an x-acto knife or similar to clean them up if necessary)
3. I have included a 'tire' for the bearing, if you have a TPE like NinjaFlex to print it with.
4. The screw has been the hardest thing for me to print, I suggest using a spiralize setting if you can and printing it with 70-100% fill.
5. The knob has a tapered thread, so you can tighten it onto the screw.

THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS
PLEASE COMMENT ANY TROUBLES SO I CAN ADDRESS THEM IN FUTURE REVISIONS

description.text: Spoolz I saw other fully printable spool holders out there, but none of them seemed to work that well. So I threw Spoolz together hoping to fill that void. It is a work in progress so please feel free to make suggestions or comments!

description.text: In this project you will use a mason jar placed over a 3d-printed pot to create a green house effect to grow plants.
Modeled a pot that can fit around a mason jar. Then I put a whole at the bottom so if I ever over watered it the water could escape.

Project: Mason Jar Pot Objectives: Students will learn about green house effects and basic planting
Audiences: Children in biology
Preparation: Soil, Printer, Plant or seeds (not too big), water, sun and a mason jar
Steps:
  • download and print file
  • add soil to pot
  • plant seeds in pot
  • put mason jar on pot
  • put everything in sun
  • if the mason jar is a little loose then use putty to secure it
    Results:
  • kids have learned about green house effects, how to 3d print their own pot, and planting.
